headline: Economic Tensions Flare in Parliament Over Job Losses and Cost of Living as Government Touts $7B Infrastructure Pipeline
summary: Parliament was the stage for a heated confrontation over New Zealand's economic direction, with the Government defending its record against Opposition attacks on job losses and rising emigration. While ministers announced a multi-billion dollar transport infrastructure pipeline and a major boost for learning support in schools, tense debates on housing, energy policy, and the cost of living dominated the day's proceedings.

topicSummaries.topic: Heated Economic Debate Erupts Over 10,000 Job Losses and Record Emigration
topicSummaries.content: A fiery exchange during Question Time saw Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins challenge Acting Prime Minister David Seymour on the state of the economy, highlighting the loss of 10,000 jobs in three months, a $720 million drop in construction sales, and a record 73,400 citizens leaving the country in the past year. Seymour defended the Government's position, describing the downturn as part of an economic cycle inherited from the previous administration and insisting a recovery is imminent. The debate became personal, focusing on recent comments from ministers regarding the unemployed.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: So which represents the Government's position on those who have lost their jobs: that they shouldn't take it personally, or that they should just put a smile on it?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (Acting Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: I know that people following at home won't have this problem, but for the Labour leader's information: the person who could do with putting a smile on it is none other than himself.

topicSummaries.content: Transport Minister Chris Bishop detailed a significant infrastructure drive, announcing that $7 billion worth of government-funded projects would begin by Christmas. Key projects highlighted include a $600 million upgrade to the Hawke's Bay Expressway starting in November, the Ōmanawa Bridge replacement in Tauranga beginning in October, and an $800 million project to remove level crossings in Auckland. Bishop framed the investment as crucial for creating thousands of jobs, improving safety, and boosting regional economies.

keyExchanges.speaker: Catherine Wedd (National—Tukituki)
keyExchanges.quote: What announcements has he made regarding the Hawke's Bay Expressway?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Minister of Transport)
keyExchanges.quote: It's fantastic to be with her and Katie Nimon to announce that construction will begin in November on the $600 million upgrade of the Hawke's Bay Expressway—a key road of national significance.

topicSummaries.topic: Homelessness Crisis Deepens Amid Policy Scrutiny
topicSummaries.content: Housing Minister Chris Bishop faced intense questioning from Green Co-leader Chlöe Swarbrick over a 90% increase in rough sleeping in Auckland. Swarbrick linked the rise to the Government's policy changes, which have seen 50% of emergency housing applications in the city declined. Bishop defended the changes, stating the Government would not return to a "free-for-all" on emergency housing that saw homelessness increase under the previous government, and argued that the solution lies in working with frontline providers and fixing the planning system, not just spending more money.

keyExchanges.speaker: Chlöe Swarbrick (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he at all see the causal connection between 50 percent of applications for emergency housing in Auckland being declined under the Government's policy changes and rough sleeping increasing by 90 percent?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Minister of Housing)
keyExchanges.quote: The official advice is that it's not possible to distinguish or associate policy changes for emergency housing and an increase in rough sleeping. That's the official advice.

topicSummaries.topic: Largest Learning Support Boost in a Generation Unveiled for Schools
topicSummaries.content: Education Minister Erica Stanford announced what she called the largest boost to learning support in a generation, funded in Budget 2025. The package includes rolling out learning support coordinators to all primary and intermediate schools over the next three years, benefiting nearly 300,000 students. The plan also makes the high-needs Ongoing Resourcing Scheme (ORS) demand-driven, extends early intervention services, and provides flexible support for small and rural schools. The Minister stated the changes address long-standing inequities and have been overwhelmingly welcomed by principals.

keyExchanges.speaker: Grant McCallum (National—Northland)
keyExchanges.quote: What announcements has she made about strengthening learning support?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Erica Stanford (Minister of Education)
keyExchanges.quote: Budget '25 delivered the largest boost to learning support in a generation. Last week, I announced the allocation of learning support coordinators (LSCs) to every school with year 1 to 8 students over the next three years.

topicSummaries.topic: Supercritical Geothermal Energy Exploration Site Announced
topicSummaries.content: Regional Development Minister Shane Jones announced the first site for supercritical geothermal exploration at the Rotokawa geothermal reservoir on Tauhara land, supported by $60 million from the Regional Infrastructure Fund. Jones described the initiative as a key contributor to New Zealand's energy resilience and a platform for future jobs, leveraging both homegrown expertise and international talent. The announcement sparked a tense political debate over the Government's repeal of the previous administration's oil and gas ban, with the Speaker repeatedly intervening to maintain order.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Kieran McAnulty (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Point of order, sir. We have canvassed this issue numerous times in the House, and you have agreed whenever we have raised concern when a Minister is expressing a political opinion on a policy of a previous Government, and to use the word "juvenile", at which point I then responded surely is not anticipating anything.

keyExchanges.speaker: SPEAKER
keyExchanges.quote: I did not hear him say "juvenile" because of exactly that sort of reaction that was going on. Mr Jones will now continue with his answer.

topicSummaries.topic: Finance Minister Faces Grilling Over Reserve Bank Governor's Resignation
topicSummaries.content: Finance Minister Nicola Willis was questioned by Labour's Barbara Edmonds regarding the resignations of the former Reserve Bank Chair and Governor. The exchange focused on recently released text messages from February, which indicated the board was considering recommending the Governor's removal. Willis defended her actions, stating she was not aware of the specific details of the employment process at the time and relied on the judgment of the Reserve Bank chair, while also reiterating her view that the chair should have handled the matter better.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Barbara Edmonds (Labour—Mana)
keyExchanges.quote: Does she really believe that New Zealanders can trust her when she has withheld information, had to correct statements, also was on the possibility of receiving advice to allow for the removal of Adrian Orr, or, really, is the real reason why Adrian Orr resigned because she drove him to it?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (Minister of Finance)
keyExchanges.quote: If Barbara Edmonds wishes to be the great defender of Adrian Orr, then that is for her. I have chosen not to politicise his exit from the Reserve Bank, which I think shows good judgment.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Defends Satellite Launch Permits for Company with Israeli Defence Links
topicSummaries.content: The Government faced questions from the Green Party's Teanau Tuiono regarding payload launch permits approved for intelligence company BlackSky, which has past links to the Israeli Defence Ministry. Foreign Minister Winston Peters, speaking for the Minister for Space, stated that advice from MBIE in December 2023 indicated no current contract existed. Peters defended the launches, noting the satellites have a wide range of general purposes, from agriculture to climate monitoring, and that the previous Labour government had also approved BlackSky payloads.

keyExchanges.speaker: Teanau Tuiono (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Can the Minister assure Kiwis that payloads launched from New Zealand on behalf of BlackSky are not being used by the Israeli Defence Ministry, in any form, to wage war in Gaza?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon WINSTON PETERS (Minister of Foreign Affairs)
keyExchanges.quote: Can I just say, very clearly, that the satellite is in the sky. What would the Greens have us do? Bring it back? I mean, the Greens might be lost in space, but the satellite is up there.

topicSummaries.topic: 72-Hectare Watts Peninsula to Become Public Reserve
topicSummaries.content: Land Information Minister Chris Penk announced that 72 hectares of land on Watts Peninsula (Mātai Moana) in Wellington will be transferred to the Department of Conservation to create a new public reserve. The move fulfils a promise made in 2011 to protect the area, which holds significant cultural, historical, and ecological value for Taranaki Whānui and the wider public. The reserve will be co-managed by a charitable trust with trustees appointed by Wellington City Council, Taranaki Whānui, and the Department of Conservation.

conclusion: The day in Parliament crystallized a core political divide: a government focused on long-term infrastructure investment and economic restructuring versus an opposition demanding immediate answers for the current pain of job losses and the rising cost of living.
